author: Michael McNulty
title: Catalyst Catapult
description: Siloed onboarding efforts lack a unified voice and vision. One-way content educates without engaging. We can't sustain on unpaid volunteers.

assessments.note: Really like the direction of this proposal, it reads exactly how decentralised organisations should progress. Granted will need further revision and governance aspects to be negotiated but meets the requirements of 'pass the baton' onboarding.

The problem and description are within the scope of the challenge. The proposal is intended to guide interested people throughout the entire process, from attracting interested people, to creating proposals or registering new members as voters or proposers. So I believe that the proposal has great potential to impact the challenge.

I do think that a more adequate onboarding mechanism would be good, however I am struggling to understand how it would work and, besides that, all the basis of Catalyst Project nowadays works with good engaged volunteering people who are already helping to create a solid growth of ADA. 
Maybe rewrite the proposal with more tangible examples in each function and provide a little bit more detail in how you see the problem and how your platform wants to solve it would be interesting.
Another thing is to clarify which are the key metrics in this proposal.

The proposal addresses several improvement points for the Catalyst on-boarding phase. The need for direct communication, mentoring, if done right can lead to a clear upgrade for both the proposers and the proposals.

The idea is great, a very good way to dissect different aspects of the Catalyst onboarding, how it could look like. It's very well structured. It might be possible to merge this with different initiatives, even if it gets funded, because there are many ideas going on regarding the onboarding topic. I believe the impact of this proposal within this challenge is huge.
Unclear what the deliverable is. The money requested is supposed to be given to others to "reward meaningful participation and contributions to the Catapult initiative". But how? Who decides?

No issues with experience (or motivation) of the author but will caution that the process needs to remain as simple as possible. Onboarding in organisations is often overdone, too much information too soon. The plan will benefit from further revision.

The proposer is already a member of the Catalyst community and is involved in some important projects and implementations, such as contributing as an organizer and facilitator of Catalyst retro sessions, participation in Swarm Sessions, as well as having other proposals for improvements in Catalyst.

I recommend including more details in the bio, so that the community has access to knowledge / expertise in an easy and transparent way.

There is a rationale for how the proposal will cause an increase value onboarding.

There is no budget breakdown. The funds will be distributed to a treasury and will be distributed to reward contributors manually (in principle), in addition different funding models will be explored in order to make the treasury self sustainable. I recommend including some structure / criteria / rationale for contributions, because without a solid model, dependence on trust would be high.

There is no timeline described in the proposal and this makes it difficult to understand the budget x time relationship.

Although in this proposal the author did not give evidence of skills, I do believe it may be feasible due to his previous experience in the challenge.
However, I have lots of doubts accounting the budget: how it would be distributed; if it's stated that a self-sustained environment needs to reward who is willing to help, how much it would really make a difference to the dedication; if the project scale, how the project will pay everybody; how it will re-monetize itself; etc.
Maybe adding a more detailed plain, actually explaining all the steps would be of a great value to this idea.

The proposer's experience as a long-time member of the Catalyst Advisor community is what must have led to the genesis of this project. He structured his proposal into 3 main points and all have been described in detail. My only question regarding the proposal is: if we reward people for the number of recruitment, how do we incentivise quality over quantity? Maybe implementing a system similar to the referral program in Catalyst, where only the funded proposals get the incentive?
What platform is this being created through. How in the incentivization scheme going to work.

The roadmap for the LOAD part is clear and it is very feasible. The other parts are also achievable but it is not that clear how this would be implemented, but from what I know about the community, it would be very feasible as well. The budget in this case might be flexible, but it would be good to have some estimate about how long this initiative would last if the proposal was funded.

I did not even understand what is being proposed here. A "mechanism for onboarding" with "three discrete but fluid functions". 
Clarification needed.

Given that we're dealing with a proposal in development the information provided is of sufficient quality to feasibly assess. The proposal strikes at the heart of the onboarding challenge and will be interesting to watch.

The problem, solution and proposal described are clear and address the challenge.

There is no roadmap, no milestones, no metrics, no KPIs.

There is no budget breakdown, it must be emphasized that the idea is that the entire budget is allocated to a treasury and that this will be distributed for contributions, but I think it is important to describe some rationale for the criteria for the distribution of these resources or perhaps the disclosure of expenses. Some model that allows auditability.

I believe that the proposal has great potential, but needs further refinement to indicate auditability.

In order to be auditable, it should add a detailed roadmap, some metrics which contain the growing number of participants, some sort of verification of relevance (since the platform is paying in advance, should be some fraud method), etc.

The on-boarding process is properly described, yet there are not enough metrics or information that would help the community measure the impact of the proposal. The proposer doesn't require any funds for this initiative, all the money will go into a treasury, that will be used for the rewarding of the volunteers. Yet, how will the contribution of each member be measured in order for him to be rewarded? Will it be a pay-per-participant, pay-per-proposer, pay-per-successfully funded participant etc? What if a CA spends a lot of time with a person, that eventually doesn't sign up, will his contribution be taken into consideration?

The project ask for funds that it will then decide on how to disburse to "meaningful participation and contributions". A plan should be provided on how this will be done and governance around it. Otherwise it risks corruption.

Since this proposal has a general and broad idea so far, and the details are not so clear, the auditability of it is somehow prejudiced. Some metrics should be included, like estimation of people onboarded in a defined period, number of veterans participating, mentors commited to the program. Since there are no concrete plan so far, it is not possible to audit the proposal properly if it's funded.

solution: Community onboarding engine sustained by incentivized stewardship and paying it forward - let's create conversational experiences together.
experience:
Engaged community member, retro organizer / facilitator  
Catalyst SWARM  
Econ/game theory/tokenomics
